title: Government finally admits Brexit won’t happen on October 31
text:
Sajid Javid made the confession despite Boris Johnson’s ‘do or die’ pledge (Picture:Rex/Metro.co.uk)

The government has been forced to backtrack on Boris Johnson’s ‘do or die’ pledge to leave the EU on October 31st.

Chancellor Sajid Javid told the BBC that the UK will not be able to leave the EU on Halloween, ‘because of the actions of Parliament’.

The Prime Minister has said he would rather be found ‘dead in a ditch’ than preside over a delay.

His hard-line stance saw the government fork out £100m pound on an advertising campaign preparing UK citizens for a no-deal Brexit on October 31st.

But in an interview today Mr Javid admitted: ‘We have to accept we won’t be able to leave on 31 October.’

A dramatic show down in the House of Commons last week saw MPs force the Prime Minister to send a letter to Brussels asking for a three month delay.

In response, the PM is now calling for a general election on December 12 to end the ‘Brexit nightmare’.

He wants to hold a vote before Christmas in exchange for giving MPs more time to scrutinise the deal he hammered out with the EU.

The move by the Tory leader comes as EU27 leaders mull over a request to grant a fresh delay to Brexit until the end of January 2020.

Under UK law, Johnson needs the support of two-thirds of MPs in order to hold an early election.

Boris Johnson wants a General Election on December 12 (Picture: Getty Images)

He said it was time for MPs to ‘make way for a new, fresh Parliament that can deliver on the priorities of the British people’.

However the Liberal Democrats, SNP and Plaid Cymru have refused to give their backing to the plan.

Labour’s Valerie Vaz told the House of Commons that the party would back an election once no-deal is ruled out and ‘if the extension allows.’

But EU leaders say they won’t make a decision on granting the UK an extension until there is clarity over the general election.
